item.title: A Theorem in Number Theory
item.description: For positive integers \(a,b\) where \(gcd(a,b) = 1\), the equation \(ax + by = n\) always has a solution in positive \(x,y\) for all \(n \geq ab\) \ Proof Since \(gcd(a,b) = 1\), by the theory of linear Diophantine equations, we know that there always exists solutions (infinitely many of them) for \(ax + by = n\). However we are only interested in the ones where both \(x\) and \(y\) are positive.

item.title: About
item.description: Student from Vizag, India who is very interested in Mathematics. On this blog, I will share elegant math problems and proofs. I also make telegram bots. You can check them out here : csgo-bot maki-management-bot Site made using Hugo
